elements.content: We report a new sensing mechanism based on an indium-dihydroxyterephthalic acid metal–organic framework (MOF, SNNU-153), in which the spatially fitted analyte-MOF hydrogen-bond (H-bond) formation provides selective recognition while the analyte-H-bond assisted excited-state intramolecular proton transfer (ESIPT) and the resulting ratiometric emission act as a superior signal transducer with ultrafast response. The synergy of ESIPT signal transduction and confined MOF pore enables the SNNU-153 sensor selectively sensing hydrazine even among nitrogen-containing hydride analogs such as NH3, NH2OH, and (Me)2NNH2. The key of H-bond and associated ESIPT was further counter evidenced by an indium-2,5-dimethoxyterephthalic acid MOF (SNNU-152), where the hydroxyl protons were removed by methylation, showing near inertness to N2H4. The new molecular recognition concept thus makes SNNU-153 a powerful N2H4 sensor, which should be far-reaching to other sensing elements.

The synergy of ESIPT signal transduction and confined MOF pore enables the SNNU-153 sensor selectively sensing hydrazine even among nitrogen-containing hydride analogs such as NH3, NH2OH, and (Me)2NNH2. The key of H-bond and associated ESIPT was further counter evidenced by an indium-2,5-dimethoxyterephthalic acid MOF (SNNU-152), where the hydroxyl protons were removed by methylation, showing near inertness to N2H4. The new molecular recognition concept thus makes SNNU-153 a powerful N2H4 sensor, which should be far-reaching to other sensing elements.

elements.content: The traditional analytical techniques available for molecular sensing are potentiometry, titration, colorimetry, chromatography, etc. These methods commonly are subject to disadvantages such as a time-consuming process, unsatisfactory sensitivity, and lack of naked-eye view capability for rapid screening. To tackle these drawbacks, fluorescent probes have been attracting immense attention owing to their superiorities of simple operation, low cost, and good sensitivity for trace detection, While the on–off signal for most of these fluorescent probes is based on the intensity change of a single fluorescence band, the precision of readout is sometimes troublesome due to the uncertain factors such as optical path length, illumination intensity, and so on.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The traditional analytical techniques available for molecular sensing are potentiometry, titration, colorimetry, chromatography, etc. These methods commonly are subject to disadvantages such as a time-consuming process, unsatisfactory sensitivity, and lack of naked-eye view capability for rapid screening. To tackle these drawbacks, fluorescent probes have been attracting immense attention owing to their superiorities of simple operation, low cost, and good sensitivity for trace detection, While the on-off signal for most of these fluorescent probes is based on the intensity change of a single fluorescence band, the precision of readout is sometimes troublesome due to the uncertain factors such as optical path length, illumination intensity, and so on.

elements.content: Alternatively, the ratiometric fluorescence sensors, which incorporate the intensity ratio for two different emission bands amid a sensing process, could efficiently overcome the above-mentioned drawbacks. In this regard, the fluorescence sensors based on the excited-state intramolecular proton transfer (ESIPT) have received considerable attention. ESIPT commonly takes place from a pre-existing intramolecular hydrogen bond (H-bond), producing a proton-transfer tautomer that exhibits a large Stokes shifted emission with respect to the normal emission (and absorption). The ratiometry for the normal versus tautomer fluorescence intensity during the analyte recognition may serve as an ideal reporting unit. Despite the progress on the ESIPT fluorescent probes, however, the quest for an omnibearing performance encompassing high selectivity, reusability, and manipulability remains challenging.

The ratiometry for the normal versus tautomer fluorescence intensity during the analyte recognition may serve as an ideal reporting unit. elements.content: In yet another approach, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have been developed into a blue-chip field; their feasibility of obtaining a serviceable functional group and diverse pore sizes of channel have led to versatile applications. A given MOF with active functionalization on the pore surface is decisive for efficient detection, providing a confined active site for interaction between host porous frameworks and specific guest molecule. In addition, an adequate pore size is also essential for the selectivity of molecular recognition. The combination of surface functionalization and pore sizes has promoted the sensing performance of MOFs for various analytes.
elements.clean_text: In yet another approach, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been developed into a blue-chip field; their feasibility of obtaining a serviceable functional group and diverse pore sizes of channel have led to versatile applications. A given MOF with active functionalization on the pore surface is decisive for efficient detection, providing a confined active site for interaction between host porous frameworks and specific guest molecule. In addition, an adequate pore size is also essential for the selectivity of molecular recognition. The combination of surface functionalization and pore sizes has promoted the sensing performance of MOFs for various analytes.

elements.content: Inspired by the above two sensing scaffolds, we thus proposed the integration of ESIPT into the MOF framework, making a powerful space-confined ratiometric fluorescence sensor. The concept lies in the fact that ESIPT requires a pre-existing H-bond where the analyte of interest and importance can provide multiple H-bonding formations. If any of the analyte-associated H-bonds can undergo ESIPT in the MOF, denoted as ESIPT-MOF, the alternation of photophyscial properties in either enhancing or suppressing ESIPT effect should result in the ratiometric changes of emission. This, in combination with the MOF providing a specific spatial confinement, may greatly boost the sensitivity and selectivity for molecular sensing.
elements.clean_text: Inspired by the above two sensing scaffolds, we thus proposed the integration of ESIPT into the MOF framework, making a powerful space-confined ratiometric fluorescence sensor. The concept lies in the fact that ESIPT requires a pre-existing H-bond where the analyte of interest and importance can provide multiple H-bonding formations. If any of the analyte-associated H-bonds can undergo ESIPT in the MOF, denoted as ESIPT-MOF, the alternation of photophyscial properties in either enhancing or suppressing ESIPT effect should result in the ratiometric changes of emission. This, in combination with the MOF providing a specific spatial confinement, may greatly boost the sensitivity and selectivity for molecular sensing.

elements.content: To prove the concept, we select the chemically important analyte hydrazine (N2H4) as a prototype, which can provide as many as four proton-donating and two proton-accepting sites. Hydrazine is an essential chemical widely used in chemical industries such as fuel cells, hydrogen carrier, and syntheses of pharmaceutical intermediates. N2H4 is also regarded as the universal fuel in missiles/rocket-propulsion systems due to its flammable and detonable characteristics. Adversely, however, it is considered as an environmental contaminant and a potential carcinogen; large-scale application of N2H4 can pose a potential threat to the environment and human health. The development of efficient sensors for the hydrazine recognition is thus of great practical importance. On this basis, ESIPT molecules such as hydroxyphenyl benzothiazole and flavone derivatives have been utilized to design ratiometric fluorescence sensors, including those for hydrazine. Also, the UiO-66 MOF has been reported for fluorescent hydrazine detection. However, the synergy of multiple H-bonds, confined space, and ESIPT to maximize the sensing performance has not been reported.
elements.clean_text: To prove the concept, we select the chemically important analyte hydrazine (N2H4) as a prototype, which can provide as many as four proton-donating and two proton-accepting sites. Hydrazine is an essential chemical widely used in chemical industries such as fuel cells, hydrogen carrier, and syntheses of pharmaceutical intermediates. N2H4 is also regarded as the universal fuel in missiles/rocket-propulsion systems due to its flammable and detonable characteristics. Adversely, however, it is considered as an environmental contaminant and a potential carcinogen; large-scale application of N2H4 can pose a potential threat to the environment and human health. The development of efficient sensors for the hydrazine recognition is thus of great practical importance. On this basis, ESIPT molecules such as hydroxyphenyl benzothiazole and flavone derivatives have been utilized to design ratiometric fluorescence sensors, including those for hydrazine. Also, the UiO-66 MOF has been reported for fluorescent hydrazine detection. However, the synergy of multiple H-bonds, confined space, and ESIPT to maximize the sensing performance has not been reported.

elements.content: After an intensive search, a common but versatile ligand, 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid (DHBDC), caught our attention, which forms porous MOF frameworks through carboxylate groups, leaving two unreacted 2,5-hydroxyl groups that form weak intramolecular H-bonds with the chelate carboxylate oxygen (vide infra). As a result, we demonstrate here, for the first time, a novel consecutive analyte H-bond assisted ESIPT process in an indium metal–organic framework (SNNU-153), which exhibits remarkable ratiometric fluorescence changes for sensing hydrazine in both solution and solid states. Importantly, much different from the conventional ESIPT sensing mechanism, the current ESIPT-MOF incorporates hydrazine inserted in the pore confined space, forming H-bonds that catalyze proton-transfer responses of hydroquinone. Such a synergistic effect in the MOF skeleton establishes a unique ESIPT process for high-performance hydrazine sensing with a very fast response, wide concentration range, and excellent durability. The details of the results and discussion are elaborated in the following sections.
elements.clean_text: After an intensive search, a common but versatile ligand, 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid (DHBDC), caught our attention, which forms porous MOF frameworks through carboxylate groups, leaving two unreacted 2,5-hydroxyl groups that form weak intramolecular H-bonds with the chelate carboxylate oxygen (vide infra). As a result, we demonstrate here, for the first time, a novel consecutive analyte H-bond assisted ESIPT process in an indium metal-organic framework (SNNU-153), which exhibits remarkable ratiometric fluorescence changes for sensing hydrazine in both solution and solid states. Importantly, much different from the conventional ESIPT sensing mechanism, the current ESIPT-MOF incorporates hydrazine inserted in the pore confined space, forming H-bonds that catalyze proton-transfer responses of hydroquinone. Such a synergistic effect in the MOF skeleton establishes a unique ESIPT process for high-performance hydrazine sensing with a very fast response, wide concentration range, and excellent durability. The details of the results and discussion are elaborated in the following sections.

elements.content: The SNNU-153 MOF sensor is built up from infinite 1-D straight chains of an indium-centered octahedron, [InO4(OH)2], connected to four neighbor chain motifs through DHBDC organic linkers. The whole 3-D architecture is of a typical MIL-53-type topology ( and Table S1). The −OH groups of adjacent DHBDC ligands are spare and close to each other with a distance of about 3.6 Å. Such a geometrical arrangement in the MOF skeleton together with the keto-enol tautomerism of hydroquinone provides an ideal example to conduct the above proposed consecutive ESIPT process for fluorescence detection of hydrazine (vide infra). As for the control, SNNU-152 MOF was also synthesized, in which DHBDC was replaced by 2,5-dimethoxyterephthalic acid to delete the hydroxyl proton. Later, we will unveil the much different behavior between SNNU-153 and SNNU-152 MOFs.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

The SNNU-153 MOF sensor is built up from infinite 1-D straight chains of an indium-centered octahedron, [InO4(OH)2], connected to four neighbor chain motifs through DHBDC organic linkers. The whole 3-D architecture is of a typical MIL-53-type topology ( and Table S1). The -OH groups of adjacent DHBDC ligands are spare and close to each other with a distance of about 3.6 Å. Such a geometrical arrangement in the MOF skeleton together with the keto-enol tautomerism of hydroquinone provides an ideal example to conduct the above proposed consecutive ESIPT process for fluorescence detection of hydrazine (vide infra). As for the control, SNNU-152 MOF was also synthesized, in which DHBDC was replaced by 2,5-dimethoxyterephthalic acid to delete the hydroxyl proton. Later, we will unveil the much different behavior between SNNU-153 and SNNU-152 MOFs.

elements.content: The synthetic routes and structures of SNNU-153 and SNNU-152 MOFs.

elements.content: As depicted in Figure S1 of the Supporting Information (SI), the absorption maximum of SNNU-153 is around 410 nm in dimethylformamide (DMF), which, upon excitation, gives a strong emission maximized at 450 nm (a). The emission has a small Stokes shift of ∼2000 cm–1 with respect to the lowest-lying absorption peak and is considered as a normal emission. A normal emission of SNNU-153 was also observed in solid samples (Figure S2). The lack of ESIPT, i.e., the proton transfer from −OH to the carboxylate oxygen, can be rationalized by the weak basicity of the coordinated carbonyl oxygen where its electron density has been shifted to the metal (In) center upon coordination.

elements.content: The absorption and emission spectra of SNNU-153 in DMF as a function of the added N2H4 concentration were then studied. Despite the smooth change of the N2H4 absorption titration spectra (Figure S1), drastic changes in ratiometric emission were observed. As shown in a, upon adding N2H4, the strong 450 nm blue emission drastically decreased, accompanied by a long wavelength shoulder that became obvious with a peak wavelength at 543 nm at a N2H4 concentration of, e.g., 100 ppm. After continually adding N2H4 from 100 to 5500 ppm, the emission intensity at 543 nm dominated the spectra with the disappearance of the 450 nm emission band. The titration established a ratiometric fluorescence pattern for hydrazine detection. The fluorescence quantum yield (QY) of the SNNU-153 450 nm band and its saturated 543 nm emission with N2H4 was measured to be as high as 18 and 49%, respectively, in DMF (Table S2). Due to the strong fluorescence intensity for both 450 and 543 nm bands, amid the N2H4 titration, SNNU-153 showed an apparent emission color change from blue to yellow that can be clearly visualized by the naked eyes under a conventional 366 nm UV light (inset of a). The sensitive fluorescence emission changes match well with the CIE chromaticity diagram (Figure S3a).

elements.content: SNNU-153 acts as a molecular sieve; therefore, the kinetic domain, i.e., the time course of reaching equilibrium for luminescence intensity at 450 and 543 nm amid N2H4 titration, is important, which was measured by in situ monitoring the real-time fluorescence intensity (b). It can be seen that the fluorescence intensity at emission 450 nm sharply decreased and quickly reached a minimum constant value in 7 and 88 s with the addition of 3.2 ppm (0.1 mM) and 1000 ppm (31.25 mM) of N2H4, respectively, showing an extraordinarily fast response for MOF-based sensors. For a fair comparison, we summarize the performance data of other reported sensors in Table S3, where the response time for most N2H4 sensing probes always exceeds 10 min. For example, the MOF sensor phthalimide-UIO-66 showed a response time of 18 min for 2.25 mM N2H4, and a common molecule sensor, EPH, exhibited a response time of 60 min when adding 1 mM N2H4.

elements.content: c shows the plot for the emission intensity at 543 nm (I 543) versus that at 450 nm (I 450) as a function of the added N2H4 concentration ([M]). Note that each measurement was made 5 min after adding N2H4 to ensure the establishment of equilibrium between N2H4 and the SNNU-153 MOF sensor (vide supra). As a result, a straight-line behavior was obtained within the added N2H4 concentration of 0–700 ppm. The linear relationship was then fitted by the Stern–Volmer relationship, i.e., I 543/I 450 = A + K SV[N2H4], and a K SV value of 406.4 M–1 was deduced. The detection limits (DLs) or limit of detection (LOD) can be estimated by the relationship DL = 3σ/k, where σ denotes the standard deviation of 10 blank tests and k is the slope of the linear relationship, which is equivalent to K SV. As a result, the detection limit was calculated to be 0.0595 ppm or 1.86 μM. Upon increasing the concentration up to 700 ppm, the deviation from the linearity gradually appeared, accompanied by the decrease of the titration slope, i.e., the ratio of I 543/I 450 versus [N2H4] (c). Nevertheless, in the [N2H4] range of 700–5500 ppm, if we qualitatively impose a linear plot, a Stern–Volmer plot with K SV of 37.76 M–1 can be obtained. The cause of perturbation in the high concentration of [N2H4] will be discussed in the later section. It is noted that the detection limit of the SNNU-153 MOF probe is superior when compared with that reported in the literature, such as BTP-LB (2.74 μM), HFP (2 μM), and CD2 (4.5 μM). Nevertheless, it is also slightly inferior to some probes, such as phthalimide-UIO-66 (0.87 μM) and 2-Ac (0.96 μM). Furthermore, the K SV value is comparable with some N2H4 probes such as BTP-LB (3.81 × 103 M–1) and BTP-LN (5.53 × 103 M–1). Overall, taking the ultrafast response performance into account, the SNNU-153 MOF probe is very promising for sensing N2H4.

elements.content: The time-resolved experiments for the SNNU-153 probe in DMF with and without N2H4 were also conducted (Figure S4). The average lifetime of the SNNU-153 probe in DMF (λem = 450 nm) is 3.21 ns. After addition of 10, 50, 100, 200, and 500 ppm of N2H4 to SNNU-153 in the DMF solution (λem = 450 nm), the average times are 2.94, 2.96, 2.99, 3.03, and 3.32 ns, respectively. The average lifetime at λem = 543 nm of SNNU-153 is 6.40 ns; after addition of 10, 50, 100, 200, 300, and 500 ppm of N2H4 to SNNU-153 in the DMF solution, the average times at λem = 543 nm are 8.06, 8.56, 9.49, 9.50, and 9.65 ns, respectively. Within the experimental error, the essentially unchanged average lifetime indicates that the fluorescence response of SNNU-153 for N2H4 originates from the ground state.

elements.content: Different from the molecule organic fluorophores, the crystalline MOF sensors offer the superiority for recycling. Accordingly, the reusability of the SNNU-153 probe was further investigated where the repeated operation with the addition N2H4 to the MOF probe in the DMF solvent and then soaked in the fresh DMF solvent, the SNNU-153 sensor clearly maintained the original fluorescence emission characters and intensity can be restored as well (d). Notably, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns show that SNNU-153 can maintain its original architecture after multiple fluorescence sensing experiments (Figure S5).

elements.content: We also investigated the fluorescence sensing of solid SNNU-153 samples to N2H4. In this experiment, the crystalline samples of SNNU-153 were dried by nitrogen on a quartz plate and placed with the N2H4 concentrated solution in a confined space. demonstrates the distinct emission color changes from bright blue to bright yellow under ultraviolet light (366 nm). This color change matches well with the phenomenon observed in the DMF solution, affirming that the superior N2H4 sensing performances of SNNU-153 are unaffected by the environment perturbation.

elements.content: The similarity of physical and chemical properties makes the separation of hydrazine from other analogous hydrides of nitrogen such as NH3, NH2OH, and (Me)2NNH2 difficult. An ideal fluorescent probe should have selectivity of N2H4 among the nitrogen hydrides. Although numerous N2H4 probes have been reported, very few of them can selectively sense N2H4 from NH3, NH2OH, and (Me)2NNH2. The synergy of multiple H-bonds (vide infra) and confined pore space of SNNU-153 offers an opportunity to achieve this superior selectivity. In the corresponding titration study for NH3, NH2OH, and (Me)2NNH2, shown in Figure S6, both fluorescence feature and intensity of the SNNU-153 sensor remain unchanged upon adding the concentration of the three tested titrants up to ∼700 ppm, which is in sharp contrast to the N2H4 titration that has undergone a drastic ratiometric change (). It is not until adding a high analyte concentration (NH3 > 1000 ppm, NH2OH and (Me)2NNH2 > 5000 ppm) that the fluorescence intensity around 450 nm starts to decrease, accompanied by the appearance of the 543 nm band (Figure S6). The results manifest their much smaller binding strength with SNNU-153 than that of hydrazine.

elements.content: Benefitting from the solid-state crystalline sensing performance of SNNU-153 (vide infra), a facile test strip for rapid naked-eye detection of N2H4 was further developed. In this application, a filter paper was utilized to filter a 6.5 mg/mL DMF solution of pure SNNU-153 crystals, which was then dried and acted as a test strip. Under UV light (366 nm), the emission color of test strips was blue (). Upon contacting with different concentrations of N2H4 in the DMF solution from 0.05 to 0.55% by weight, the filter paper exhibited a prompt emission color change from blue to yellow under UV light. Under the same concentrations, conversely, NH3, NH2OH, and (Me)2NNH2 showed a negligible change in emission. The instant naked-eye detection suggests a rapid on-site probe for N2H4 in pragmatic applications.
elements.clean_text: Benefitting from the solid-state crystalline sensing performance of SNNU-153 (vide infra), a facile test strip for rapid naked-eye detection of N2H4 was further developed. In this application, a filter paper was utilized to filter a 6.5 mg/mL DMF solution of pure SNNU-153 crystals, which was then dried and acted as a test strip. Under UV light (366 nm), the emission color of test strips was blue (). Upon contacting with different concentrations of N2H4 in the DMF solution from 0.05 to 0.55% by weight, the filter paper exhibited a prompt emission color change from blue to yellow under UV light. Under the same concentrations, conversely, NH3, NH2OH, and (Me)2NNH2 showed a negligible change in emission. The instant naked-eye detection suggests a rapid on-site probe for N2H4 in pragmatic applications.

elements.content: The high performance of the SNNU-153 sensor for hydrazine is attributed to the superior N2H4/SNNU-153 complexation and ratiometric emission to boost recognition and signal transduction. While the former takes advantage of the multiple H-bonding formations and confined space of MOF, the latter is proposed to originate from the H-bond assisted excited-state proton transfer, giving rise to the highly sensitive ratiometric emission elaborated below.

elements.content: The free ligand DHBDC exhibits an S0 → S1 absorption maximum at 350 nm in DMF, while the emissions are located at ∼500 nm. The large anomalously Stokes shifted emission of >8000 cm–1 can be ascribed to ESIPT from the −OH group to the carbonyl CO oxygen of the carboxyl group (Figure S7), resulting in a proton-transfer tautomer emission. This is essentially the same phenomenon as the seminally reported 2-hydroxybenzoic acid (salicylic acid) where ESIPT takes place from the hydroxyl proton to carbonyl oxygen upon electronic excitation. In sharp contrast, the pristine SNNU-153 reveals absorption and emission maxima at 410 nm (Figure S1) and 450 nm (), respectively. Their spectral mirror image makes the assignment of normal emission unambiguous. The observation of the normal emission infers that ESIPT does not take place in SNNU-153. This can be rationalized by the fact that the carbonyl oxygen of DHBDC, upon coordination with the indium ion, has decreased its basicity by forming the formate anion. Support of this viewpoint is also given by the absorption spectral red shift from DHBDC (350 nm) to SNNU-153 (410 nm).

The large anomalously Stokes shifted emission of >8000 cm-1 can be ascribed to ESIPT from the -OH group to the carbonyl CO oxygen of the carboxyl group (Figure S7), resulting in a proton-transfer tautomer emission. In sharp contrast, the pristine SNNU-153 reveals absorption and emission maxima at 410 nm (Figure S1) and 450 nm (), respectively. Their spectral mirror image makes the assignment of normal emission unambiguous. The observation of the normal emission infers that ESIPT does not take place in SNNU-153. This can be rationalized by the fact that the carbonyl oxygen of DHBDC, upon coordination with the indium ion, has decreased its basicity by forming the formate anion. Support of this viewpoint is also given by the absorption spectral red shift from DHBDC (350 nm) to SNNU-153 (410 nm).

elements.content: Upon adding N2H4, shown in Figure S1, the absorption peak of SNNU-153 blue shifted from 410 to 353 nm, which more plausibly indicates the rupture of the intramolecular hydroxyl-carboxylate H-bond by the formation of the N2H4/SNNU-153 intermolecular H-bond. Commonly, the intramolecular H-bond causes the elongation of the π conjugation, hence lowering the energy gap. Once ruptured and replaced by the intermolecular H-bond, the induced π-electron delocalization ceased, resulting in the rise of the energy gap. Moreover, upon monitoring at the 543 nm emission band, the peak wavelength of the excitation spectrum is at 355 nm (Figure S8). The result clearly indicates that the 543 nm emission originates from the ground-state species that has 353 nm absorption. The Stokes shift between 353 nm absorption and 543 nm emission peaks is then calculated to be as large as ∼10,000 cm–1. The anomalous spectral changes in both absorption and emission lead us to propose the occurrence of excited-state proton transfer reaction upon forming the N2H4/SNNU-153 H-bonded complex.

elements.content: To gain further insights into the corresponding H-bonding structure and the associated proton-transfer mechanism, we then performed the computational approach to simulate the N2H4/SNNU-153 H-bonded complex formation. The computational approaches were performed at the B3LYP level with the 6-31+G* + LANL2DZ (on the In atoms) mixed basis set using the Gaussian 09 program package. Based on the coordinate of the SNNU-153 measured by X-ray crystallography analyses, a model structure AH2 is then constructed and shown in Figure S9. This model consists of one DHBDC2– ligand that is coordinated with four In­(III) ions through the carboxylate group simultaneously. In addition, each In­(III) ion is coordinated with two formate anions to maintain the octahedron geometry of each six-coordinated indium ion. Finally, the adjacent In­(III) ions are bridged by OH– for truncation and charge balance to keep neutralization.

The computational approaches were performed at the B3LYP level with the 6-31+G* + LANL2DZ (on the In atoms) mixed basis set using the Gaussian 09 program package. Based on the coordinate of the SNNU-153 measured by X-ray crystallography analyses, a model structure AH2 is then constructed and shown in Figure S9. This model consists of one DHBDC2- ligand that is coordinated with four In(III) ions through the carboxylate group simultaneously. In addition, each In(III) ion is coordinated with two formate anions to maintain the octahedron geometry of each six-coordinated indium ion. Finally, the adjacent In(III) ions are bridged by OH- for truncation and charge balance to keep neutralization.

elements.content: We then performed full optimizations for the stable structures of the DHBDC ligand. In the optimized model AH2, the In–O bond lengths between the carboxylic acid and In ion are 2.096–2.153 Å and the distance between the two adjacent indium ions is 3.616 Å, which are very close to the corresponding values in SNNU-153 (In–O bond is 2.141–2.184 Å, and indium–indium distance is 3.585 Å), indicating that the current model can well simulate the real crystal structure.

elements.content: Based on the above, we then optimized the AH2 geometrical structures upon encapsulating hydrazine. The result shows that AH2 and each hydrazine form as many as three H-bonds at two symmetric −OH sites, i.e., a stoichiometric 2:1 N2H4/SNNU-153 H-bonded complex (a), where the distances between N–H and O–H are 1.840, 2.246, and 2.279 Å, respectively. Based on the optimized structure at the B3LYP/6-31+G­(d)&LANL2DZ level, we calculated the interaction energy between AH2 and N2H4 at the B3LYP-D3/6-311++G­(d)&LANL2DZ level with counterpoise correction. The interaction energy, E int, is estimated to be −17.27 kcal/mol, which, in combination with the confinement imposed by SNNU-153 to compensate the entropy loss, explains the high K SV upon complexation (vide supra).

elements.content: To rationalize the dual emission, we then further propose that the excitation of this 2N2H4/SNNU-153 complex undergoes proton transfer in the excited state. This process involves the transfer of the DHBDC hydroxyl proton that forms the H-bond with N2H4 to the nitrogen site of N2H4, resulting in a zwitterionic species in the excited state shown in b. Considering the 2N2H4/SNNU-153 H-bonded complex as a molecular identity, such a process can be treated as an intramolecular process, i.e., ESIPT, and the term ESIPT will be used hereafter. This ESIPT process is not uncommon because most of the phenolic proton, upon ππ* excitation, becomes much more acidic than its ground state. In an aqueous solution, upon electronic excitation, the phenolic hydrogen will be ejected and stabilized by the surrounding water molecules. In other words, the phenolic proton is commonly denoted as the ″photoacid″ where the excited-state deprotonation takes place in an aqueous solution. In aprotic solvents, however, the ejected proton, if there were any, could not be effectively stabilized, so the excited-state deprotonation is prohibited unless a basic group is introduced that forms a H-bond with the hydroxyl proton either intra- or intermolecularly. In the case of the 2N2H4/SNNU-153 complex, it is reasonable to propose the occurrence of ESIPT from the proton donor, i.e., the hydroxyl proton, to the proton acceptor, i.e., the nitrogen of the complexed N2H4, giving rise to a 543 nm tautomer emission in DMF. We then apply time-dependent (TD)-DFT calculation to optimize the excited-state structures of both the normal N2H4/SNNU-153 species and the proton-transfer species (Figure S9c–d), and their corresponding frontier orbitals are shown in Figure S10. Note that due to the truncated MOF structure, the simulation of the ESIPT potential energy surface has little physical meaning. Instead, we are interested merely in the thermodynamic relationship between normal and proton-transfer zwitterionic tautomer species. The results shown in c indicate that the zwitterionic tautomer species is lower in excited-state energy than that of normal species by 8.3 kcal/mol (0.36 eV). Although the calculated absolute energies have been underestimated compared to the experimental spectra, the results support the energetically favorable ESIPT process. Note that this approach is based on the single proton transfer, while the 2N2H4/SNNU-153 H-bonded complex provides two potential ESIPT sites in a symmetric manner. However, as for the low power excitation such as the steady-state measurement, in theory, ESIPT should be a single proton transfer process despite the two potential ESIPT sites for the 2N2H4/SNNU-153 H-bonded complex.

elements.content: Both X-ray structure and computational simulation indicate that the porous size of SNNU-153 (crossing dimensions of about 8 × 15 Å) is large enough to accommodate more than two hydrazine molecules if more N2H4 molecules are allowed to be encapsulated. Therefore, under high N2H4 concentration, considering the capability of multiple H-bonds that both SNNU-153 and N2H4 can provide, it is reasonable to expect a high stoichiometric ratio of X:1 N2H4/SNNU-153 H-bonded formation where X > 2. This leads to the complexity of N2H4 titration at a high concentration, as evidenced by the deviation of ratios of fluorescence intensities for 543 nm versus 450 nm as a function of the N2H4 concentration at >700 ppm. Due to the X > 2 stoichiometry, K SV is expected to decrease, rationalizing the experimental results (cf. K SV in the region of 0–700 pm, ).

elements.content: Last but not the least, to support the above computational simulation, chemically, we provide further experimental evidence via sensing N2H4 with another MOF, namely, SNNU-152 (). SNNU-152 possesses a similar structure with SNNU-153 except that the ligand DHBDC is replaced by DMOBDC (2,5-dimethoxyterephthalic acid) () where the hydroxyl proton has been removed by methylation. As a result, both N2H4 absorption and emission titration experiments for SNNU-152 show slight changes of emission intensity but a negligible spectral shift in the added N2H4 concentration of 0–1000 ppm (Figure S11). The results manifest the dual functionalities of the hydroxyl proton in the N2H4 recognition. First, for SNNU-153, it provides the additional O–H ··· N2H4 H-bonding formation to strengthen the N2H4/SNNU-153 complex for recognition. Second, upon excitation, the hydroxyl proton undergoes ESIPT, resulting in the zwitterion 543 nm emission, which, together with the N2H4 unbound SNNU-153 450 nm normal emission, serves as a superior signal transducer based on ratiometric emission. It is the synergy among multiple H-bonds, confined space, and ESIPT that makes SNNU-153 a superior N2H4 sensor in both sensitivity and selectivity.

As a result, both N2H4 absorption and emission titration experiments for SNNU-152 show slight changes of emission intensity but a negligible spectral shift in the added N2H4 concentration of 0-1000 ppm (Figure S11). The results manifest the dual functionalities of the hydroxyl proton in the N2H4 recognition. First, for SNNU-153, it provides the additional O-H ⋅⋅⋅ N2H4 H-bonding formation to strengthen the N2H4/SNNU-153 complex for recognition. elements.content: In conclusion, summarizes the proposed consecutive analyte H-bond assisted ESIPT process for N2H4 detection by the SNNU-153 MOF sensor. In the ground state, the N2H4 titration establishes an equilibrium between free SNNU-153 MOF and N2H4/SNNU-153 H-bonded MOF complex, which, upon excitation, gives normal 450 nm and proton-transfer tautomer 543 nm emission, respectively. The interchanges between these two species in the excited state are too slow to compete with other excited-state relaxation processes and hence are dynamically forbidden. Also, the rate of ESIPT is ultrafast, as evidenced by the system-response rise (≪300 ps) of the 543 nm emission. Therefore, the ratio of the emission intensity essentially reflects the N2H4 titration in the ground state. The consecutive analyte H-bond assisted ESIPT process in the confined space of metal–organic frameworks is unique, which renders a remarkable capability for turning off–on ratiometric fluorescence detection of hydrazine. Also, benefitting from the synergy among multiple H-bonds, specific pore space of MOF, and ESIPT phenomenon, the SNNU-153 sensor exhibits rapid sensing ability, wide response concentration range, good repeatability, and importantly great selectivity of hydrazine from its analogs NH3, NH2OH, and (Me)2NNH2.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion,  summarizes the proposed consecutive analyte H-bond assisted ESIPT process for N2H4 detection by the SNNU-153 MOF sensor. In the ground state, the N2H4 titration establishes an equilibrium between free SNNU-153 MOF and N2H4/SNNU-153 H-bonded MOF complex, which, upon excitation, gives normal 450 nm and proton-transfer tautomer 543 nm emission, respectively. The interchanges between these two species in the excited state are too slow to compete with other excited-state relaxation processes and hence are dynamically forbidden. Also, the rate of ESIPT is ultrafast, as evidenced by the system-response rise (≪300 ps) of the 543 nm emission. Therefore, the ratio of the emission intensity essentially reflects the N2H4 titration in the ground state. The consecutive analyte H-bond assisted ESIPT process in the confined space of metal-organic frameworks is unique, which renders a remarkable capability for turning off-on ratiometric fluorescence detection of hydrazine. Also, benefitting from the synergy among multiple H-bonds, specific pore space of MOF, and ESIPT phenomenon, the SNNU-153 sensor exhibits rapid sensing ability, wide response concentration range, good repeatability, and importantly great selectivity of hydrazine from its analogs NH3, NH2OH, and (Me)2NNH2.

cln_elements.content:
As depicted in Figure S1 of the Supporting Information (SI), the absorption maximum of SNNU-153 is around 410 nm in dimethylformamide (DMF), which, upon excitation, gives a strong emission maximized at 450 nm (a). The emission has a small Stokes shift of ∼2000 cm–1 with respect to the lowest-lying absorption peak and is considered as a normal emission. A normal emission of SNNU-153 was also observed in solid samples (Figure S2). The lack of ESIPT, i.e., the proton transfer from −OH to the carboxylate oxygen, can be rationalized by the weak basicity of the coordinated carbonyl oxygen where its electron density has been shifted to the metal (In) center upon coordination.

The absorption and emission spectra of SNNU-153 in DMF as a function of the added N2H4 concentration were then studied. Despite the smooth change of the N2H4 absorption titration spectra (Figure S1), drastic changes in ratiometric emission were observed. As shown in a, upon adding N2H4, the strong 450 nm blue emission drastically decreased, accompanied by a long wavelength shoulder that became obvious with a peak wavelength at 543 nm at a N2H4 concentration of, e.g., 100 ppm. After continually adding N2H4 from 100 to 5500 ppm, the emission intensity at 543 nm dominated the spectra with the disappearance of the 450 nm emission band. The titration established a ratiometric fluorescence pattern for hydrazine detection. The fluorescence quantum yield (QY) of the SNNU-153 450 nm band and its saturated 543 nm emission with N2H4 was measured to be as high as 18 and 49%, respectively, in DMF (Table S2). Due to the strong fluorescence intensity for both 450 and 543 nm bands, amid the N2H4 titration, SNNU-153 showed an apparent emission color change from blue to yellow that can be clearly visualized by the naked eyes under a conventional 366 nm UV light (inset of a). The sensitive fluorescence emission changes match well with the CIE chromaticity diagram (Figure S3a).

SNNU-153 acts as a molecular sieve; therefore, the kinetic domain, i.e., the time course of reaching equilibrium for luminescence intensity at 450 and 543 nm amid N2H4 titration, is important, which was measured by in situ monitoring the real-time fluorescence intensity (b). It can be seen that the fluorescence intensity at emission 450 nm sharply decreased and quickly reached a minimum constant value in 7 and 88 s with the addition of 3.2 ppm (0.1 mM) and 1000 ppm (31.25 mM) of N2H4, respectively, showing an extraordinarily fast response for MOF-based sensors. For a fair comparison, we summarize the performance data of other reported sensors in Table S3, where the response time for most N2H4 sensing probes always exceeds 10 min. For example, the MOF sensor phthalimide-UIO-66 showed a response time of 18 min for 2.25 mM N2H4, and a common molecule sensor, EPH, exhibited a response time of 60 min when adding 1 mM N2H4.

c shows the plot for the emission intensity at 543 nm (I 543) versus that at 450 nm (I 450) as a function of the added N2H4 concentration ([M]). Note that each measurement was made 5 min after adding N2H4 to ensure the establishment of equilibrium between N2H4 and the SNNU-153 MOF sensor (vide supra). As a result, a straight-line behavior was obtained within the added N2H4 concentration of 0–700 ppm. The linear relationship was then fitted by the Stern–Volmer relationship, i.e., I 543/I 450 = A + K SV[N2H4], and a K SV value of 406.4 M–1 was deduced. The detection limits (DLs) or limit of detection (LOD) can be estimated by the relationship DL = 3σ/k, where σ denotes the standard deviation of 10 blank tests and k is the slope of the linear relationship, which is equivalent to K SV. As a result, the detection limit was calculated to be 0.0595 ppm or 1.86 μM. Upon increasing the concentration up to 700 ppm, the deviation from the linearity gradually appeared, accompanied by the decrease of the titration slope, i.e., the ratio of I 543/I 450 versus [N2H4] (c). Nevertheless, in the [N2H4] range of 700–5500 ppm, if we qualitatively impose a linear plot, a Stern–Volmer plot with K SV of 37.76 M–1 can be obtained. The cause of perturbation in the high concentration of [N2H4] will be discussed in the later section. It is noted that the detection limit of the SNNU-153 MOF probe is superior when compared with that reported in the literature, such as BTP-LB (2.74 μM), HFP (2 μM), and CD2 (4.5 μM). Nevertheless, it is also slightly inferior to some probes, such as phthalimide-UIO-66 (0.87 μM) and 2-Ac (0.96 μM). Furthermore, the K SV value is comparable with some N2H4 probes such as BTP-LB (3.81 × 103 M–1) and BTP-LN (5.53 × 103 M–1). Overall, taking the ultrafast response performance into account, the SNNU-153 MOF probe is very promising for sensing N2H4.

The time-resolved experiments for the SNNU-153 probe in DMF with and without N2H4 were also conducted (Figure S4). The average lifetime of the SNNU-153 probe in DMF (λem = 450 nm) is 3.21 ns. After addition of 10, 50, 100, 200, and 500 ppm of N2H4 to SNNU-153 in the DMF solution (λem = 450 nm), the average times are 2.94, 2.96, 2.99, 3.03, and 3.32 ns, respectively. The average lifetime at λem = 543 nm of SNNU-153 is 6.40 ns; after addition of 10, 50, 100, 200, 300, and 500 ppm of N2H4 to SNNU-153 in the DMF solution, the average times at λem = 543 nm are 8.06, 8.56, 9.49, 9.50, and 9.65 ns, respectively. Within the experimental error, the essentially unchanged average lifetime indicates that the fluorescence response of SNNU-153 for N2H4 originates from the ground state.

As depicted in Figure S1 of the Supporting Information (SI), the absorption maximum of SNNU-153 is around 410 nm in dimethylformamide (DMF), which, upon excitation, gives a strong emission maximized at 450 nm (a). The emission has a small Stokes shift of ~2000 cm-1 with respect to the lowest-lying absorption peak and is considered as a normal emission. A normal emission of SNNU-153 was also observed in solid samples (Figure S2). The lack of ESIPT, i.e., the proton transfer from -OH to the carboxylate oxygen, can be rationalized by the weak basicity of the coordinated carbonyl oxygen where its electron density has been shifted to the metal (In) center upon coordination.

The absorption and emission spectra of SNNU-153 in DMF as a function of the added N2H4 concentration were then studied. Despite the smooth change of the N2H4 absorption titration spectra (Figure S1), drastic changes in ratiometric emission were observed. As shown in a, upon adding N2H4, the strong 450 nm blue emission drastically decreased, accompanied by a long wavelength shoulder that became obvious with a peak wavelength at 543 nm at a N2H4 concentration of, e.g., 100 ppm. After continually adding N2H4 from 100 to 5500 ppm, the emission intensity at 543 nm dominated the spectra with the disappearance of the 450 nm emission band. The titration established a ratiometric fluorescence pattern for hydrazine detection. The fluorescence quantum yield (QY) of the SNNU-153 450 nm band and its saturated 543 nm emission with N2H4 was measured to be as high as 18 and 49%, respectively, in DMF (Table S2). Due to the strong fluorescence intensity for both 450 and 543 nm bands, amid the N2H4 titration, SNNU-153 showed an apparent emission color change from blue to yellow that can be clearly visualized by the naked eyes under a conventional 366 nm UV light (inset of a). The sensitive fluorescence emission changes match well with the CIE chromaticity diagram (Figure S3a).

SNNU-153 acts as a molecular sieve; therefore, the kinetic domain, i.e., the time course of reaching equilibrium for luminescence intensity at 450 and 543 nm amid N2H4 titration, is important, which was measured by in situ monitoring the real-time fluorescence intensity (b). It can be seen that the fluorescence intensity at emission 450 nm sharply decreased and quickly reached a minimum constant value in 7 and 88 s with the addition of 3.2 ppm (0.1 mM) and 1000 ppm (31.25 mM) of N2H4, respectively, showing an extraordinarily fast response for MOF-based sensors. For a fair comparison, we summarize the performance data of other reported sensors in Table S3, where the response time for most N2H4 sensing probes always exceeds 10 min. For example, the MOF sensor phthalimide-UIO-66 showed a response time of 18 min for 2.25 mM N2H4, and a common molecule sensor, EPH, exhibited a response time of 60 min when adding 1 mM N2H4.

 c shows the plot for the emission intensity at 543 nm (I 543) versus that at 450 nm (I 450) as a function of the added N2H4 concentration ([M]). Note that each measurement was made 5 min after adding N2H4 to ensure the establishment of equilibrium between N2H4 and the SNNU-153 MOF sensor (vide supra). As a result, a straight-line behavior was obtained within the added N2H4 concentration of 0-700 ppm. The linear relationship was then fitted by the Stern-Volmer relationship, i.e., I 543/I 450 = A + K SV[N2H4], and a K SV value of 406.4 M-1 was deduced. The detection limits (DLs) or limit of detection (LOD) can be estimated by the relationship DL = 3σ/k, where σ denotes the standard deviation of 10 blank tests and k is the slope of the linear relationship, which is equivalent to K SV. As a result, the detection limit was calculated to be 0.0595 ppm or 1.86 μM. Upon increasing the concentration up to 700 ppm, the deviation from the linearity gradually appeared, accompanied by the decrease of the titration slope, i.e., the ratio of I 543/I 450 versus [N2H4] (c). Nevertheless, in the [N2H4] range of 700-5500 ppm, if we qualitatively impose a linear plot, a Stern-Volmer plot with K SV of 37.76 M-1 can be obtained. The cause of perturbation in the high concentration of [N2H4] will be discussed in the later section. It is noted that the detection limit of the SNNU-153 MOF probe is superior when compared with that reported in the literature, such as BTP-LB (2.74 μM), HFP (2 μM), and CD2 (4.5 μM). Nevertheless, it is also slightly inferior to some probes, such as phthalimide-UIO-66 (0.87 μM) and 2-Ac (0.96 μM). Furthermore, the K SV value is comparable with some N2H4 probes such as BTP-LB (3.81 × 103 M-1) and BTP-LN (5.53 × 103 M-1). Overall, taking the ultrafast response performance into account, the SNNU-153 MOF probe is very promising for sensing N2H4.

The time-resolved experiments for the SNNU-153 probe in DMF with and without N2H4 were also conducted (Figure S4). The average lifetime of the SNNU-153 probe in DMF (λem = 450 nm) is 3.21 ns. After addition of 10, 50, 100, 200, and 500 ppm of N2H4 to SNNU-153 in the DMF solution (λem = 450 nm), the average times are 2.94, 2.96, 2.99, 3.03, and 3.32 ns, respectively. The average lifetime at λem = 543 nm of SNNU-153 is 6.40 ns; after addition of 10, 50, 100, 200, 300, and 500 ppm of N2H4 to SNNU-153 in the DMF solution, the average times at λem = 543 nm are 8.06, 8.56, 9.49, 9.50, and 9.65 ns, respectively. Within the experimental error, the essentially unchanged average lifetime indicates that the fluorescence response of SNNU-153 for N2H4 originates from the ground state.
